Not recommended, I played this since the early beta of Overwatch 1 and beta tested Overwatch 2. This was a game promised to "change how we view sequels" through adding PvE missions, branching skill trees, a replayable endgame. What we got was a dozen features shaved off Overwatch 1, a store slapped onto it, Heroes that were previous free locked behind a paywall, and new content in general being locked behind battlepasses and monetization only.

This is not a good free to play game at all. It does not respect your time and you will become incredibly frustrated with it if you try to go without paying. The good heroes are all premium and locked behind battle passes or bundles, and if you try to go into ranked without those heroes you will be flamed and lose a significant amount of times you could have won if you just had the good heroes.

This is a money grab by Blizzard and the developers who created this mess should be ashamed of themselves. They took what was considered a game of the year, and ran it into the ground for pure profit and short term gains.

This game was so promising in the beggining, back in 2016, but after a total discouragement and lack of proper leadership within the ranks of Blizzard Entertainment, greedy CEOs that turned the game full into microtransactions and paywalls for the original content, I can no longer recommend this game. It sucks badly, not because the in-game things, but the company behind it, the betrayal to the fanbase, the lack of diversity in the competitive ranks and also the deceptive propaganda that Blizzard constantly puts everywhere.-

The entire reason behind OW2 was the PVE content, promised years ago. Now they stripped that away, they put it behind a disgusting paywall and all those who bought the original game feel like this is a very bad dream. I don't have proper words to describe my dissapointment.

I hope someday the game will die properly, and remembered as the "all-time-fiasco" of Blizzard Entertainment.

TL;DR: A fun, yet hollow game that does not respect it's players and wishes to draw as much cash as possible out of you - it is merely a shadow of what the game used to be.

Overwatch 2 is nothing but a shell of the fantastic game it once was. All game features were, once, provided to a player right off the bat, alongside a forgiving and (mostly) entirely free cosmetic system. Overwatch 2 was introduced as a replacement, or "upgrade" to the original game, and though some arguments can be made that this was the case there also many features which are objective downgrades.

It is upsetting to see a game I was a huge fan of, even back in it's beta in 2016, turn into a shameless front designed to pillage as much money from it's players as possible. Story content, practically all cosmetics, even heroes - compounded around the most parasitic and vile form of monetisation in the industry: the battle pass, which is in of itself packed with filler garbage that is worth next to nothing to the majority of players.

If you wish to play a fun team-based hero shooter: be my guest. Despite the game's flaws and clear inferiority to it's predecessor, Overwatch 2 still contains the gameplay that made it initially stand out many years ago. But do stay aware that the game you are playing is utterly inferior in nearly all ways to it's previous incarnation.

I have spent almost 900 hours on this game since the Overwatch 1 days and I plan to play more. I love the games hero interactions, the fast, dynamic and exciting gameplay that just makes me keep coming back. The heroes and their personalities is something that other games struggle to capture the same charm as this game does. The 5v5 transition was the best thing for the game that makes it far fresher and exciting. Tank is actually fun to play in the 5v5 setting which is something I would never say before the update. The games thematic prowess about heroism in an optimistic future make it stand out from other games in the hero shooter genre. Even though the criticisms of the games story missions pricing, gutting of PvE and microtransations are rightfully criticised. Blizzard sucks donkey and the microtransations are terrible (good skins but overpriced). Neither of those have infringed on the sheer enjoyment this game brings me and many others who love the world and characters. Overwatch 2 is still a game I keep coming back to. From a thematic standpoint its a game that reminds me that even when the world is riddled with awful people that bring it down into darkness. Our world, regardless of how terrible and bleak it may seem, is a future worth fighting for.

DO NOT PLAY THIS GAME OR GET INTO IT! (ABSOLUTE GARBAGE!)
It's been clear for years that this game has been slowly dying. The lack of support for OW1 in its lifespan and the esports scene losing a lot of iconic pros has contributed to the state it is in now. Blizzard does not care about the game or its player base, its clear by the monetization scheme and the super over priced skins they are pumping out that offer little to no change at all. I used to be happy every event OW had, now I'm not because I have to pay to get a skin compared to before where I could get it for free by grinding and getting lucky in lootboxes. The balance is horrific and they either go real deep into the right direction, but then they dive heavily into a wrong direction. The game lost its soul a long time ago, and its sad to see the state its in. Please don't support this stingy greedy company.

[h1]I broke my promise to never play Overwatch ever again, just so I can write this review.[/h1]


[b][i]Short:[/i][/b] Don't bother, if you've played the original Overwatch you can call this a scam. If you want the original Overwatch experience, or as close as it can get, play Team Fortress 2. The game that inspired the whole franchise. 

[b][i]Long:[/i][/b] I've played the original Overwatch since day 1. It was fun, but I quickly realized that all the hype around it was, well... overhyped. The game played as advertised, but could get stale after a while due to the same meta. 
Overwatch 2 was meant to be the successor. First being "OW1 but with PVE", offering cross play between the two versions. But eventually they killed the original and forced everyone to go to OW2.

[list]
[*]Balance is badly done. Going from 6 to 5 characters per team caused a lot of power imbalance. The main tank can't take all that damage, so they had to buff the healers, which in turn caused the damage class to deal more damage as the healers were too powerful.
[*]Heroes are now behind a pass. Either you buy it and get to play it immediately, or level up till 50 to unlock it. Missed the deadline? Don't worry you can buy the hero in the store when the new pass rolls out.
[*]Visuals and art is laughable. They claimed that OW2 would be a step up, but all they really did was change the weather and time of day on most maps. Changed the audio of the weapons and the looks of the heroes and called it a day. The artwork for the heroes also feels bland and lifeless compared to the original.
[*]Monitization is extreme. Cheap cosmetics and overpriced crap. The free way is slow and will take months to buy one legendary piece. I haven't touched OW2 and my account is valued at around 2000-2500 euro just from playing the original game alone. I didn't spend any money in the first one.
[*]PVE was the driving force for this game. But they cancelled it and sold the remaining pieces to you for a price. But don't worry, you'd get some high value cosmetics for it in return! What a steal!
[/list]

[h1]This game only exists to get money from you. Lootboxes weren't generating enough money, so they just made an elaborate scheme to get you from one monitization plan to another.[/h1]

[h1]Where to even begin?[/h1]
[b]Positives:[/b] 
-You can leave a negative review on Steam for it and actually voice your criticism, as opposed to BattleNet where that is not an option.

[b]Negatives.[/b]
-Terrible hero balance
-Bland graphics
-Maps made by people who don't understand how to make competitive maps
-Game modes that are functional garbage like Push
-A team game where team communication is through the floor
-Harbors and encourages a toxic community where no one actually has any fun and the competitive mode actively ruined people's outlook on the entire game
-Removed two entire players from the match in a misguided attempt to balance the game
-New heroes are buy or grind only, so much for OW1's claim that all future content updates would be free!
-Cancelled the PvE mode after using it as the justification for deleting OW1 and forcing people to migrate to OW2
-Blizzard, the company, reguarly sees controversy and desperately deflects any attempts at criticism. Read any other negative Steam review for more info
-Overwatch League.
-Blizzard, the company, doesn't respect your time, money, nor YOU. 
-Blizzard is so desperate for new blood for their game they bend the knee to VALVe to allow their games on Steam after keeping their games off other platforms for up to 20 years beforehand.

[h1]Please, PLEASE stay away from this game.[/h1]
This game's great when you don't have someone in your ear telling you it's bad

The tldw version of my manifesto is you're better off playing Paladins or TF2 if you're looking for class based free to play FPS. OW2 is a shallow corporate whore in comparison. 

I've been playing Overwatch on and off since 2016 before the game first launched. I've never been amazing at OW1 but it's been more fun than not. At the very least it seemed like it was in good hands back when Jeff Kaplan was at the helm. In interviews he mentioned how he had to fight the higher ups for things like free updates, heroes, free events, etc. Jeff wasn't some "gamer messiah" but he appeared to be the rare AAA developer who wasn't trying to squeeze as much money as possible out of the game.

Overwatch 2 is terrible in that regard. Going "Free to Play" not only ruined this game but ruined the franchise's reputation. And all the hate Blizzard gets for it is deserved (aside from the harassment of employees but that's obviously not what I mean lol). The executives at Blizzard have pushed the devs into monetising every aspect of the game they can get away with.

- Converting real money into fake currency is a well documented manipulation tactic used by game companies to get you to spend more. They also do the thing where the amount of scam currency they sell you is just under the price of everything forcing you to spend more than you would. Want an item for 2000 coins? Well sorry but the only way to buy coins is in packs of 1400 or 2500 (this is just an example, I don't remember any specific prices). On top of all of that there are exclusive skin packs in the shop that cost over 25$ CAD for a single legendary skin (and technically a spray and voiceline or some shit too but come on). Keep in mind that the brand new fancy Mythic skins which are a rarity higher than legendary can be unlocked from the 15$ battle pass.

- All cosmetics have had their prices multiplied. On top of that they've included a ton of brand new cosmetic items that are completely forgettable and useless just because they needed more garbage to fill out their brand new battle pass. You can also now buy skins directly from the

- Battlepasses. You get to pay for the opportunity to experience FOMO. After all, if you don't complete the battlepass in time then that's a waste of money. So you either need to grind the game like it's your job OR you can pay even more money to skip ahead. If you're going to play a game that much regardless then it's not so bad, especially if the battlepass can give you enough currency for the next one. But game companies are sneaky, they know the majority of the playerbase won't earn enough fake currency to pay for the next battlepass nevermind actually complete the thing.

- There's the PvE aspect that was originally touted as the whole reason why Overwatch added a 2. It was supposed to take the basic PvE missions from the first game and turn them into both a full fledged co-op campaign and PvE missions designed to be infinitely replayable thanks to things like skill trees, changes in objectives and enemies, etc. The latter got cancelled recently however, probably because Blizzard realized they could make more money making skins than actual gameplay content. As for the former? idk giving money to blizzard feels dirty lmao

- This is the most egregious one of all. I could ignore all that other shit if this one thing wasn't a problem:

                                                                     Paying for heroes.

"Other games charge you for new characters (except Dota I hear but I wouldn't know)", "you're selfish/greedy/entitled expecting gameplay for free in a free to play game", "you have to pay for development costs", "it's only [insert USD prices] so actually it's cheaper than buying a full game", "the characters are free if you just wait or play a lot", etc etc. 

The key difference with those other games and OW2 is how Overwatch's gameplay is built around switching heroes mid-match. Being able to swap and counter the opponent in the middle of the round was a core aspect since day 1 and WHY Jeff Kaplan fought so hard for free heroes. Maps, team comps, individual heroes, gamemodes, these are all designed with swapping and counters in mind. Heroes are purposely designed to counter certain strategies while being weak others. If you don't have all the heroes then that's thrown out completely. Imagine playing rock paper scissors except you don't have access to rock, or playing poker but only you can't use hearts. You are left at an innate disadvantage even if the opponent doesn't know it. What's the term where players can pay money to gain advantages over their free to play opponents called again?

It's not about the price itself, though 10-15$ every few months is still a lot more money than the 0$ veteran players are used to. It's more about the principle. You mean to tell me that despite ALLL the other ways Blizzard has monetized the game they STILL wouldn't have enough money to continue releasing heroes for free? Fine, sure. Then what about a compromise? There's currently an option to buy all of the OW2 heroes up to this point for like, 20$ or something. Add another 10 or 20$ on there but extend it to all FUTURE heroes as well. It'd almost be like you're paying for a video game or something idk.

Also no, spending 15-20+ hours grinding the free battlepass/hero challenge doesn't count as the heroes being free. Treating the game like a job while blizzard is advertising their store and skins and currency to you at all times still means you're paying them. It's just not with money. The 5v5 gameplay is fun but not that fun.

In conclusion fuck hanzo.
